Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China Graphical abstract The reaction of ethylene and acetic acid to produce vinyl acetate (VAM) was investigated on Pd-Au nanoparticles (NPs) supported on TiO2. Compared with the commercial catalyst Pd-Au/SiO2, Pd-Au/TiO2 exhibited a higher turnover frequency (TOF), likely due to the formation of smaller Pd-Au NPs (∼1.9 nm) and metal support interactions (MSI) between TiO2 with Pd-Au NPs. We found that the oxygen vacancies (OVs) of the TiO2 were regulated by adjusting the reduction temperature, facilitating electron transfer from TiO2 to the Pd-Au NPs, leading to enhanced MSI. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (In situ DRIFTs) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicated that the electron-rich Pd-Au NPs of Pd-Au/TiO2 catalyst enhanced O2 activation for increased TOF, and also promoted AcOH dehydrogenation and the key reaction of ethylene and acetate coupling. Our findings demonstrated that reducible supports could effectively influence the electronic properties of Pd-Au NPs through the construction of MSI, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. Keywords Heterogeneous catalysis Metal-support interaction Oxygen vacancy Vinyl acetate TiO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As the largest acetic acid derivative, vinyl acetate is an important building block used extensively in producing fibers, solar modules, and soil conditioners [1–4]. In industry, compared to the acetylene method for vinyl acetate monomer (VAM) synthesis, the ethylene method over Pd-Au/SiO2 catalysts is widely used due to the safety of ethylene as a raw material, the avoidance of waste residue, and the high product quality. This catalyst, first described by Hoechst and Bayer in the 1980s [5], is a Pd-Au alloy supported on SiO2, with alkali metal acetate, such as KOAc, acting as an accelerator. Through the electronic [6] and ensemble effects [7], the PdAu alloy exhibits higher activity and selectivity compared to pure Pd in the catalyst. Au can isolate the continuous Pd ensemble, resulting in a highly active surface location. The ideal Pd atomic pair interval for catalyzing the reaction is around 3.3 Å [8–12]. The presence of Au also influences the electrical characteristics of Pd, increasing the electron density in the d-band of Pd [13,14]. This reduces the intensity of ethylene adsorption on Pd, thereby preventing the active sites from being occupied due to excessive adsorption [12]. The introduction of promoter KOAc, which donates electrons to Pd, also affects the electronic properties of Pd-Au nanoparticles (NPs), significantly enhancing the activity and selectivity [15–19]. While the effects of additional metals and promoters on VAM catalysts have been extensively studied, the impact of different supports has been largely overlooked [20]. Due to the inert nature of the silica support, Pd-Au cannot achieve additional metal-support interactions to enhance catalytic activity, limiting further reduction of metal consumption. Compared to relatively inert silica support, properties such as reducibility [21,22] and acidity [20] of metal oxides can directly influence the surface characteristics of the supported noble metals, which in turn affects the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. Metal-support interaction (MSI) between non-inert supports and NPs often leads to the emergence of new interfacial phenomena. The MSI can provide a profound impact on the performance of metal nanoparticles. Constructing MSI between reducible supports and noble metals can significantly influence the dispersion, oxidation state, and catalytic performance of the supported metals [23]. MSI can originate from various origins. For example, the encapsulation of dispersed metal nanoparticles by a reducible oxide support is known as strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [24–26]. MSI also includes charge transfer between the support and NPs, changes in particle morphology, and alterations in the chemical composition of NPs [27]. This interaction can be achieved by introducing oxygen vacancies (OVs) to the surface of support [28]. OVs on supports loaded with noble metals act as electron donors, creating electron-rich metal sites. These sites could significantly enhance catalytic performance in CO2 reduction [29], dry reforming of methane [30], and organic oxidation reactions [31,32]. The resulting enhanced O2 activation [33,34] and H-spillover [32] are expected to be advantageous factors in the production of vinyl acetate. In this work, we synthesized and characterized the Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs catalyst and compared its performance with the commercial Pd-Au/SiO2 catalyst. The formation mechanism of OVs on TiO2 was also investigated, and the effect of OVs on metal NPs was analyzed. Experimental and theoretical methods (Density Functional Theory, DFT) were implemented, which indicated that OVs on TiO2 can regulate the electronic properties of Pd-Au NPs, promoting key reactions and accelerating VAM formation, thus enhancing the overall catalyst performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials KOAc (AR, ≥99 %), AcOH (GR, ≥99.8 %), Urea (≥99.5 %), PdCl2 (≥99.9 % metals basis), and HAuCl4·3H2O (≥99.9 % metals basis) were acquired from Aladdin, TiO2 (P25) (≥99.5 % metals basis) commercial carriers from Evonik, and C2H4 (≥99.999 %), O2 (≥99.999 %), N2 (≥99.999 %), 10 % H2/Ar from Boliming Gas Company. None of the reagents or gases were refined further. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalyst samples were prepared using the deposition–precipitation (DP) [31,35]. A typical preparation technique was as follows. First, 5 g of TiO2 (P25) was dispersed in 68 g of deionized water, followed by a solution of PdCl2 (0.15 mol/L, 1.5 mL) and HAuCl4 (0.12 mol/L, 0.42 mL). The nominal mass loadings of Pd and Au were 0.48 wt% and 0.20 wt%, respectively. The solution was kept at 80 °C and stirred continuously for 10 min, avoiding light. Then, urea solution (5.15 g in 140 g deionized water) was added to the mixture, which was used as a precipitating agent and a molar ratio of 100 with metal ions. The catalyst sample was continuously mixed until the terminate pH = 6, filtered, and washed before drying at 80 °C for 12 h. It was then heated to 400 °C at 5 °C/min under 10 % H2/Ar gas flow for 4 h. After cooling, the sample was impregnated with 1.0 mol/L potassium acetate solution (1.5 g) and dried at 110 °C with flowing air for 12 h. The resulting catalyst sample was named as Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs. Unless otherwise stated, the Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs catalyst in this work was all prepared using the typical preparation described above. The reduction temperature was changed to label the resulting catalyst as Pd-Au/TiO2-X, for example when the reduction temperature was 550 °C, the resulting catalyst was labeled as Pd-Au/TiO2-550. The reduction temperature of the catalyst was indicated here, leaving out the OVs to avoid too long a name. Their preparation procedures were identical, except that the temperature of the reduction treatment was different. 2.3 Catalyst characterization To characterize the specific surface area and pore properties of the catalysts, nitrogen (N2) physisorption was carried out at −196 °C using a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 analyzer. Prior to the physisorption measurement, the catalysts were degassed at 200 °C for 12 h. The specific surface areas were calculated from the isotherms by applying the BET equation. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Rigaku MiniFlex 600 X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source. The diffractograms were scanned with a step size of 0.02◦ in the 2θ range of 20 ∼ 60◦. Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM) was performed on a JEOL JEM-ARM200F equipped with an automated aberration correction system operated at 200 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and the High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental maps were performed on a Thermo Scientific Talos F200X operated at 200 kV. Elemental contents were determined on an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Agilent 720es). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) was measured by a Thermo Scientific Nexsa system equipped with Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV) with an X-ray anode operated at 12.5 kV. The C 1s peak (284.8 eV) was used to calibrate the binding energy (BE) values. ESR spectra was collected on a JES-FA200 machine (JEOL, Inc.). The ESR spectra was performed at a microwave frequency of 9.44 GHz at 298 K without light irradiation. The scanning speed was 30 s per sweep, and the spectra was averaged based on 30 sweeps. Raman scattering measurements were recorded on a confocal Raman Spectroscopy (Renishow, inVia reflex), and the wavelength was set as 532 nm. XRD, Raman, and ESR characterizations were performed at room temperature and in air atmosphere. All samples were transferred without additional vacuum or inert gas protection after reduction. H2-TPR and H2-titration were performed using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). H2-titration was used to obtain the amount of surface exposure of the active center Pd for the calculation of turnover frequency (TOF) [36]. The metal dispersion, metal surface area, and metal particle size can be calculated using the following calculation parameters: V chem / m o l ∙ g - 1 : Chemical adsorption capacity, SF : The number of adsorption sites on the catalyst surface occupied by each adsorbed molecule, for Pd and H2, SF was determined to be 2, MW : Atomic weight of the supported metal, c / w t % : Amount of metal supported, σ m / nm 2 : Cross-sectional area of supported metal, the value of σ m for Pd atom is 0.0787 nm2, based on the atomic radius, ρ / g ∙ cm - 3 : Density of supported metal. The chemical adsorption capacity was determined by the total amount of hydrogen consumed, which was determined with theTCD peak area. Metal dispersion: (1) D m % = Number o f m e t a l a t o m s h e l d Chemisorption s i t e × 100 (2) = V chem ∙ S F ∙ M W c 100 × 100 Metal surface area (per gram of catalyst): (3) A m m 2 g = V chem ∙ 6.02 × 10 23 ∙ S F ∙ σ m ∙ 10 - 18 Average particle diameter: (4) S m n m = 6 c A m × 100 × ρ × 10 6 × 10 9 (5) = 60 c A m × ρ TOF was calculated from the following formula: (6) T O F h - 1 = STY MW VAM × ρ cat × V chem × S F ρ cat / g ∙ L - 1 : Density of catalyst STY / g VAM ∙ L CAT - 1 ∙ h - 1 : Average space–time yield of VAM In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) experiments were performed on a Bruker INVENIO FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a liquid-N2-cooled HgCdTe (MCT) detector. A high-temperature reaction chamber equipped with ZnSe windows, mounted on a Praying Mantis diffuse reflectance accessory (Harrick Scientific), was used for the in situ gas-phase analysis of catalyst samples. All spectra were measured with a resolution of 2 cm−1 and an accumulation of 32 scans. In the in situ DRIFTS high-temperature reaction chamber, 150 mg of the catalyst was placed for the in situ diffuse reflectance experiment of ethylene to VAM reaction. Initially, the reaction chamber was evacuated to 1.0 × 10 - 5 Pa, and the sample was heated to 160 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, holding for 2 h to remove surface adsorbates, followed by scanning the background spectrum. Subsequently, N2 was introduced at 14.1 mL/min, along with AcOH at a flow rate of 0.015 mL/min, with the inlet line heated to 160 °C and the cell maintained at 65 °C to avoid any AcOH condensation. After 2 h, the AcOH adsorption signal reached saturation, and C2H4 was introduced at a flow rate of 16.8 mL/min. After another 2 h, the C2H4 signal stabilized, at which point the N2 feed was switched to 16.9 % O2/N2 feed, continuously monitoring the diffuse reflectance spectrum changes. During the reaction, the temperature of the reaction chamber was maintained at 160°C, and the total pressure was 100 kPa. Under reaction conditions, the feed mixture consisted of 45.6 vol% C2H4, 16 vol% AcOH, and 6.5 vol% O2 (bal. N2). 2.4 VAM reaction evaluation All experiments for catalyst performance in VAM synthesis were carried out in a fix-bed continuous flow system. The reactor consists of a 13.5 mm inner diameter and 420 mm stainless steel tube filled with a 2 g catalyst. The catalyst powder was first pressed into pellets, then crushed and sieved to 20 ∼ 40 mesh for activity evaluation. The mixture contained ethylene, oxygen, and AcOH with volume fractions of 45.6 %, 6.5 %, and 16.0 %, respectively, along with 31.9 % nitrogen as an internal standard and diluent. The liquid AcOH was pumped into the preheater at 160 °C, mixed with ethylene nitrogen, and then entered the reactor. The reaction conditions were as follows: the reactor temperature was maintained at 160 °C under an excess pressure of 0.8 MPa, and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was kept at 2000 h−1. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (Shimadzu, GMS-QP2020 NX) with Restek Rtx-624 capillary column (1.8 μm × 320 μm × 30 m) was used for continuous analysis. CO2, N2, and O2 were quantitatively analyzed by mass spectrum peak area, while C2H4 was quantified by FID peak area. When analyzing the liquid phase, cyclohexane with a known mass was added to the fully condensed liquid as an internal standard to determine the STY of VAM. VAM and CO2 were considered to be the only detectable carbon-containing products. The equations for the main reaction to form VAM and CO2 were as follows: (7) C 2 H 4 + 1 2 O 2 + H O A c → V A M + H 2 O Δ G Θ = - 146 k J mol - 1 (8) C 2 H 4 + 3 O 2 → 2 C O 2 + 2 H 2 O Δ G Θ = - 1339 k J mol - 1 The selectivity of VAM was calculated according to the following equation: (9) S VAM = 4 p VAM 4 p VAM + p C O 2 where p VAM and p C O 2 are the partial pressures of VAM and CO2, respectively. 2.5 Computational details Spin-polarized DFT-D3 calculations were performed with Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [37,38], the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [39,40] and a plane-wave basis set with a cutoff energy of 500 eV was employed, where Becke-Jonson (BJ) damping was used [41,42]. For all calculations in this work, the generalized gradient approximation with Perdew − Burke − Ernzerhof functionals (GGA-PBE) [43] was used to describe the electronic exchange correlation interaction. The Brillouin zone was sampled with a 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack grid [44]. The convergence criteria for the electron energy and the maximum atomic force are 1 . 0 × 10 - 5 eV and 0.02 eV Å−1, respectively. Transition states (TSs) were located by using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [45,46] and the Dimer method [47]. All TSs were confirmed by frequency analysis. For TiO2 (P25), the anatase (1 0 1) surface is the dominating active exposure surface (>94 %), which has been confirmed in previous studies [48–51]. Therefore, the 4 × 3 anatase TiO2 (1 0 1) surface was modeled as a periodic slab with three OTiO layers. The vacuum layer between slabs was set to 20.0 Å to avoid the interaction between neighboring lattices. During the structural optimizations, all the atoms except the lowest TiOTi are allowed to relax. Such slab models have been demonstrated to be accurate enough in recent studies [52–55]. The model of a support with OVs was built by removing one oxygen atom from the top layer [56–58]. All the structures of PdxAuy/TiO2-OVs were confirmed using the ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) approach. Pd4Au1 and Pd9Au4 NPs were considered to increase generality. Using the Nosé-Hoover thermostat scheme [59,60], AIMD simulation was run in an NVT ensemble with a temperature of 433.15 K, a time step of 1.0 fs, and a simulation duration of 10.0 ps. The Bader Charge Analysis [61] code was applied to determine the electrons exchanged between two counterparts. For commercial Pd-Au/SiO2, The PdAu (1 1 1) surface was modeled by a four-layer slab with a (4 × 4) surface unit cell, where thepositions of all atoms except for those in the two bottom layers were fully relaxed. The PdAu (1 1 1) crystal plane is the most exposed surface of the PdAu alloy [15]. The Pd (1 1 1) or PdAu (1 1 1) crystal plane is also crucial for catalyzing the synthesis of vinyl acetate monomer (VAM) from ethylene. In the entire model, the Pd to Au atomic ratio was set at 1:1, which was close to the reported active phase composition [62]. In fact, regardless of the initial composition of the active phase before the reaction, the optimal active phase with a Pd to Au atomic ratio of 1:1 will be preserved due to the migration and reorganization of Pd [16,62]. The Pd and Au atomic ratio on the slab surface was set to 3:1. Pd atoms were initially located in the bulk phase and segregated to the alloy surface as the reaction proceeded. This modeling approach has been recognized in several reported studies [4,63]. The settings for the vacuum layer, cutoff energy, k-points, and convergence accuracy follow those mentioned earlier. The adsorption energy of surface species was calculated as: (8) G ads = G total - G slab - G X where G total , G slab , and G X were the free energies of the X absorbed on the slab and the bare surface of the slab and free adsorbate in the gas phase, respectively. Since the reaction for ethylene to vinyl acetate generally occurs at 433.15 K, VASPKIT [64] was used in the calculations to correct the free and adsorbed molecules at 433.15 K. The reaction energy ( Δ G ) was defined as the total energy difference between the initial state ( G IS ) and the final state ( G FS ) of the basic surface reaction. The activation energy barrier was calculated by Δ G a = G TS - G IS , where G TS was the free energy of transition state. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and nanostructure characterization of Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms indicated that both the support and the catalysts exhibit typical mesoporous characteristics (Fig. S1, Table 1 ). The slight increase in surface area and pore volume upon loading Pd-Au precursors suggested that the deposition succeeded and provided additional surfaces for adsorption. Subsequent high-temperature reduction had almost no impact on the pore structure of the catalysts. The contents of different elements in each catalyst were shown in Table 2 . We maintained consistent Pd and Au loadings across catalysts obtained at different reduction temperatures to eliminate the influence of metal content on properties and activity of catalysts. The addition of alkali acetate promoters during the catalytic process of vinyl acetate was a well-established practice, and we adopted this approach in this work. KOAc is generally thought to enhance the adsorption of acetic acid, facilitating the transfer of sufficient acetic acid and acetate species to the PdAu surface [16]. This process helps AcOH compete more effectively with ethylene for adsorption sites, promoting the coupling between ethylene and acetate species, thereby improving both the activity and selectivity of the catalyst [18]. Furthermore, KOAc can interact with Pd to form Pd-acetate species, which may alter the surface composition of the Pd-Au NPs and even increase the local Pd-Pd distances [17]. This effect would prevent the formation of continuous Pd ensembles on the Pd-Au surface, inhibiting the strong adsorption of CHx species and providing an optimal geometric arrangement for active sites. The K+ ion content in commercial catalyst is 22 g · L Cat - 1 , suggesting that alkali acetate promoters will also play a significant promoting role in this reaction. In this work, however, we focus more on the effect of the support on the dispersion and electronic effect of Pd-Au NPs and how these factors further influence the catalytic reaction. To minimize the impact of varying K+ ions content on this process, we ensured that all catalysts were prepared with the same K+ ions content. Table 3 listed the metal dispersion and average particle size for all catalysts, calculated from data obtained via H2-titration. Figs. 1 f, g, S2, and S3 presented the particle size distribution of Pd-Au NPs measured directly from HAADF-STEM images. In the HAADF-STEM images, the average particle size of Pd-Au NPs at reduction temperatures of 150 °C to 450 °C ranged from 1.9 nm to 2.3 nm, while at 550 °C, the particle size increased to an average of 3.4 nm. From the average particle sizes of Pd-Au NPs measured via H2-titration at different reduction temperatures, we found different results. For catalysts using TiO2 as a support, the average particle sizes of Pd-Au NPs measured by the H2-titration method were relatively large. An increase in average particle size was noted starting at 350 °C, reaching a maximum at 400 °C, with little difference in average particle size between 450 °C and 550 °C. The preparation method of Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs catalyst was described in Fig. 1a. AC-HAADF-STEM confirmed that highly dispersed Pd-Au NPs were loaded on TiO2. Compared to commercial Pd-Au/SiO2, the average particle size was reduced from 3.9 nm to 1.9 nm, and the metal dispersion increased from 28.7 % to 35.1 % (Figs. 1f, g, and S1, Table 3). Pd and Au form a uniform alloy within the nanoparticles, as confirmed by EDS (Fig. S4). The highly dispersed Pd-Au NPs were also verified by XRD. Due to the smaller average particle size of the Pd-Au NPs, the diffraction peaks of the Pd-Au NPs were invisible (Fig. 3c). In Figs. 1c and S5, contrast variations can be observed along the direction of the yellow arrows, which were caused by changes in the thickness of the atomic columns of TiO2. The edge thickness of TiO2 was uniform within the focal plane, which was confirmed by the clear boundary of TiO2 in Fig. S5, where the metal-support interface was absent. However, along the direction of the white arrows, darker regions can be directly observed on the TiO2 surrounding the Pd-Au NPs at the edge of TiO2, which can be attributed to OVs (Fig. 1b–d). The formation of OVs can lead to the removal of oxygen atoms, leaving two excess electrons each OV. These electrons were captured by nearby Ti atoms, inducing the formation of Ti3+ ions near the surface. Changes in the valence state of metal ions can manifest as different contrasts in HAADF-STEM imagines. As a result, the Ti3+ ions induced by OVs exhibited lower contrast in HAADF mode, resulting in darker regions [65,66,67]. The DP method is particularly suitable for preparing Au-TiO2 catalysts, as the efficient interaction between Au precursor ions and TiO2 in solutions of different pH often results in small and highly dispersed NPs [68]. However, due to the differing adsorption strengths of TiO2 for Pd and Au precursor ions, further investigation was required to regulate the actual loadings of Pd and Au during the DP process. This is of great significance for the industrial application of such catalysts, as the Pd/Au ratio often needs to be adjusted to balance catalytic activity and cost. We initially used the same nominal amounts of Pd and Au precursor salts, and terminating the DP process at different pH values (Fig. 2 a). The actual Au loading remained relatively constant, while the Pd loading progressively decreased from 0.37 % to 0.20 %. This indicated that increasing the termination pH of DP process reduced the actual Pd loading, but had no effect on the final Au content. Furthermore, we conducted the DP process with varying nominal Pd and Au loadings while keeping the termination pH at 8.5 (Fig. 2b). The actual Au loading correlated with the nominal Au content, while the actual Pd loading showed little dependence on the nominal Pd content, even when only Pd or Au precursor salts were used. The actual loadings of Au and Pd were independently influenced by the nominal precursor content and the termination pH of DP process, allowing convenient control over the desired loadings and ratios of Au and Pd.. 3.2 The generation of metal-support interaction TiO2 structure was retained after loading Pd-Au NPs and introducing OVs, as confirmed by Raman and XRD (Fig. 3a–c) [32,69,70]. Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs exhibited characteristic Raman peaks Eg, B1g, and A1g, attributed to TiO2. Compared to TiO2, the peaks of Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs slightly shifted to higher wave numbers, which can be attributed to the OVs generated in Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs [71]. Additionally, the introduction of OVs in TiO2 reduced the concentration of OTiO vibrational units, thereby weakening the intensity of the Raman peaks. The OVs in the catalyst and support were detected by EPR. There was no obvious EPR peak in TiO2, while a symmetric and sharp EPR signal at g = 2.003, corresponding to OVs, was observed in Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs (Fig. 3i) [72]. Due to spin–orbit splitting, two XPS peaks of Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 were detected in the Pd 3d region of the Pd-Au/SiO2 catalyst, with binding energies of 335.3 eV and 340.6 eV, respectively (Fig. 3g and h). The binding energy of the Pd 3d region was similar to that of Pd0, at 335.0 e V (Pd 3d5/2) and 340.4 eV (Pd 3d3/2), respectively [19]. Pd2+ peaks can be seen because Pd NPs are easily oxidized when they come into contact with O2 in air or water at ambient temperature [31,33]. Similarly, in the 4f region of Au, two peaks of Au 4f7/2 and Au 4f5/2 were detected, with binding energies of 83.5 eV and 87.2 eV, respectively, which were similar to the binding energies of Au0 of 84 eV (Au 4f7/2) and 87.7 eV (Au 4f5/2) [20]. In Pd-Au/SiO2, Pd and Au primarily exist as Pd0 and Au0, which were determined to be active sites traditionally. Compared to Pd-Au/SiO2, the binding energy of Pd0 on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs was shifted to lower B.E. by 1.6 eV and 1.3 eV, respectively, while the binding energy of Au 4f7/2 and Au 4f5/2 was similarly decreased by 0.8 eV and 0.9 eV, respectively (Fig. 3d and e). This suggested that electron transfer from TiO2-OVs to Pd was more probable, resulting in electron-rich NPs [33]. The XPS spectra of O 1s consisted of two peaks located at 530.7 eV and 529.1 eV, corresponding to hydroxyl signals from water and lattice oxygen, respectively. Attributing the signal at 530.7 eV to oxygen vacancies was a contentious interpretation, as it has been reported that vacancies can quickly oxidize under ambient conditions [73]. Due to the high adsorption energy of water at vacancy sites, ambient water can swiftly occupy the oxygen vacancies of metal oxides, effectively oxidizing the vacancies and filling them with oxygen from the water. The additional H atoms generated can form hydroxyl groups with remaining surface oxygen, contributing to the hydroxyl signal [74]. Fig. S6 displayed the XPS spectra of Ti 2p, revealing a small area of Ti3+ signal, indicating the formation of a TiO2-x structure with a slight loss of oxygen atoms to create oxygen vacancies after reduction. The formation of OVs was limited due to the small interface between the NPs and the support [66]. Combined with EPR and Raman spectroscopy, this suggested that even after exposure to ambient conditions, a small quantity of oxygen vacancies remained on TiO2. These vacancies may be located beneath the surface of the anatase structure, which could explain their resistance to quenching by adsorbates [75]. Furthermore, atomic-resolution HAADF-STEM images revealed the formation of specific vacancies around the supported Pd-Au NPs on the anatase TiO2 crystal, correlating with the vacancies resolved in EPR and Raman spectra. Typically, reducing clean TiO2 surface requires temperatures exceeding 900 K and several hours of reduction, indicating that the NPs play a crucial role in promoting the reduction of the surrounding TiO2 [65]. The TiO2-OVs transferred electrons to NPs, and the metal-support interaction was established via electron transfer [27]. We demonstrated that by adjusting the reduction temperature of the catalyst, the strength of the MSI between TiO2-OVs and NPs can be controlled. As the reduction temperature increased from 150 °C to 550 °C, the binding energies of Pd 3d and Au 4f in the XPS initially decreased and then increased. Combined with the trend in OVs content acquired by EPR, it was demonstrated that the interaction intensity between Pd and Au with the TiO2 support was regulated by the content of OVs in TiO2 (Fig. 4 a–c). Interestingly, as the reduction temperature rose above 400 °C, the content of OVs in the catalyst began to decrease. It could be proposed that Pd-Au NPs activated H2 via H-spillover, making the formation of OVs easier. When the catalyst reduction temperature exceeded 400 °C, Pd-Au NPs sintered, reducing the contact sites between support and metal. This reduced the content of OVs on thecatalyst and weakened the MSI strength. XRD patterns of catalysts obtained at different reduction temperatures revealed that Pd-Au bimetallic diffraction peaks (2 θ = 39.1°, between 38.2° and 40.1° attributed to Pd (1 1 1) and Au (1 1 1), respectively) formed in the catalysts reduced at 550 °C, suggesting that NPs on catalyst were agglomerated, as confirmed by particle size distribution obtained from HAADF-STEM images (Figs. S3 and S7). H2-TPR analysis revealed that the reduction peak of the TiO2 support in Pd-Au/TiO2 shifted to 300 °C, directly indicating the role of Pd-Au NPs in facilitating the formation of OVs around them (Fig. S8). 3.3 Activity and selectivity for vinyl acetate Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs exhibited the same STY of VAM as Pd-Au/SiO2 (Table 4 and Fig. 5 ), where the TOF was 1.6 times that of Pd-Au/SiO2 (280 h−1 to 480 h−1), under the same reaction condition. Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs achieved the same catalytic performance as Pd-Au/SiO2 while using only half the metals, as confirmed by ICP-OES (Table 2). The increase in reaction activity can be attributed to the reduction in the average particle size of the NPs and the enhanced metal-support interactions, as confirmed by characterization results. To further validate this, we conducted H2-titration to determine the metal dispersion and the TOF for each catalyst (Table 5 ). Based on the surface chemisorbed H2 capacity measured by H2-titration, the metal dispersions for Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs and Pd-Au/SiO2 were determined to be 35.1 % and 28.7 %, respectively, with corresponding TOF of 480 h−1 and 280 h−1. Both the increase in metal dispersion and the enhanced catalytic activity of Pd sites contributed to the improvement in reaction activity. Since the TOF calculation method was based on the number of surface exposed sites measured through H2-titration, it reflected the intrinsic activity of the catalytic sites, thereby excluding the influence of changes in catalyst particle size. The enhanced TOF at the active catalytic sites could be attributed to changes in the electronic properties of Pd induced by OVs. To explore this, we systematically tested Pd-Au/TiO2-X catalysts obtained at different reduction temperatures (X ranged from 150 °C to 550 °C, which brought different OVs content). Their TOF for synthesizing vinyl acetate exhibited a volcano-like trend, suggesting that the TOF of the catalytic active sites was related to changes in OVs content (Fig. 6 ). The particle size distribution of catalysts shown in Fig. S3 indicated that increasing the reduction temperature up to 450 °C had little impact on particle size growth, while Pd-Au NPs tended to agglomerate at 550 °C. Combining the particle size data calculated based on HAADF images (Fig. S3), we found that the average particle sizes of Pd-Au NPs measured by H2-titration were relatively large. This might be due to the coverage of active sites caused by strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) [26], which reduced the available sites for H2 adsorption, ultimately leading to an overestimation of the measured size. This observation was consistent with the trends in OVs content and changes in the binding energy of metal across different catalysts, directly reflecting the strength of interactions between metal and support. The catalyst reduced at 400 °C exhibited the highest TOF, while the number of exposed active sites decreased at this temperature. The combined effects of these two factors ultimately resulted in a slight increase in the STY of vinyl acetate (Tables 4 and 5). The STY of vinyl acetate significantly decreased for the catalyst reduced at 550 °C, coinciding with an increase in the average particle size of Pd-Au NPs and a reduction in TOF of active sites. This indicated that the strength of MSI affected the TOF of active sites, and the coverage of surface sites due to strong SMSI and particle sintering collectively influenced the number of active sites. The overall activity of catalysts was thus impacted by both the number of active sites and their TOF. At the same time, we found that for the other two important by-products besides CO2 (acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate), Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs can reduce their STY by half compared with Pd-Au/SiO2 catalyst, which will be of great significance for the subsequent separation process. 3.4 Mechanism and Insights The mechanism by which OVs enhanced metal-support interactions was further validated by Bader charge analysis and differential charge density studies (Fig. 7 a–d). Different sizes of NPs were loaded on TiO2 and TiO2-OVs surfaces. All structures experienced a 10 ps relaxation using ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) approach (Figs. S9 and S10) [76]. Based on the stable structures from AIMD, Bader charge analysis revealed that Pd-Au NPs exhibited a greater local charge density when bound to TiO2-OVs compared to TiO2 support (Fig. 7a–d). This suggested that electrons were transferred from TiO2-OVs to NPs, consistent with XPS results. Both positively and negatively charged metal atoms were present in the NPs, which could be explained by the electronegativity differences between different elements (O > Au > Pd > Ti). Underlying metal atoms, which are directly bonded with O, tend to lose electrons. On the surface of TiO2 with OVs, this trend was suppressed, and some metal atoms even gained electrons, forming electron-rich metal species. The presence of OVs significantly increased the binding energy of NPs with TiO2 (−6.04 vs. −7.58 eV, −8.89 vs. −12.04 eV), indicating an enhanced interaction between metal and support. The electronic property analysis of the catalyst models suggested that OVs induced the formation of electron-rich Pd-Au NPs and enhanced MSI between Pd-Au NPs and TiO2. The adsorption of C2H4, AcOH, and O2 on the surface of two catalysts was studied (Table 6 ). Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs significantly weakened the adsorption of ethylene and the adsorption energy (−139.8 kJ/mol → −94.6 kJ/mol), while the adsorption of O2 and AcOH was enhanced. On industrial catalysts, strong adsorption of ethylene can lead to further dehydrogenation, carbon deposition, or deep oxidation to CO2, which was considered to be one of the reasons for catalyst deactivation [77,78]. The adsorption energy of VAM on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs was lower than that on Pd-Au/SiO2, indicating that the desorption of VAM on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs was easier. Two recognized pathways for VAM generation on Pd-Au catalyst are Samonos and Moiseev mechanisms, which were examined in detail (Fig. 7e, f and Table 7 ) [5,8,13,15,79–81]. The Samonos mechanism involves the coupling of ethylene and acetic acid, followed by β-H elimination, TheMoiseev mechanism involves the direct coupling of dehydrogenated vinyl species and acetic acid. The molecular oxygen is first adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst and then dissociated to form the active O* species. The H* species generated in the reaction process reacts with the O* to form OH*, and OH* further reacts with the H* species to form water. Finally, the water is desorbed from the catalyst surface to complete the catalytic cycle. All optimized structures of the initial (IS), transition (TS), and final states (FS) were listed in SI (Figs. S11–S18). For theSamonos mechanism, the rate-determining step for all catalysts was the coupling between C2H4* and CH3COO*. The energy barrier of this step (TS 4) was lower on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs compared to Pd-Au/SiO2 (142 kJ/mol → 123 kJ/mol). For theMoiseev mechanism, the rate-determining step for all catalysts was the coupling process between C2H3* and CH3COO*. The energy barrier for this step (TS 3) was higher on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs compared to Pd-Au/SiO2 (100 kJ/mol → 170 kJ/mol). The mechanism for VAM formation on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs clearly followed the Samonos mechanism, which was always a controversial topic in Pd-Au/SiO2 [82–84]. O2 adsorption on Pd can be improved by donating electrons from Pd species to the anti-bonding π * orbital of O2 [85]. Electron-rich Pd has a greater ability to adsorb and activate O2, contributing to the oxidation process of organic materials [33,34,86]. This study confirmed that the adsorption energy of O2 increased from 78 kJ/mol to 98 kJ/mol (Table 6). Additionally, the barrier for O2* dissociation to active O* species significantly decreased from 85 kJ/mol to 38 kJ/mol on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs (TS 6) compared to Pd-Au/SiO2. TiO2-OVs supplied electrons to NPs, and these electron-rich Pd-Au NPs facilitated the activation of O2 on Pd-Au surface, promoting the removal of surface H* during VAM synthesis, a key step in the process [87,88]. Previous studies have shown that the presence of surface H* species can hydrogenate CH2CH* intermediates to form CH3CH* species [89]. These CH3CH* species can then react with CH3COO* to produce ethyl acetate as a byproduct, which has similar properties to vinyl acetate and is difficult to separate. As a result, the fact that Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs produced only half the amount of ethyl acetate compared to Pd-Au/SiO2 further confirmed their enhanced ability to remove surface H* species. Moreover, the barrier for the dehydrogenation of AcOH to form CH3COO* intermediate species (TS 2) was lower on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs (52 kJ/mol → 37 kJ/mol), indicating that Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs also promoted the activation and dehydrogenation of AcOH. In situ DRIFTS investigated the surface species changes on Pd-Au/SiO2 and Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs under reaction conditions. Catalysts were first saturated with AcOH and C2H4 (Fig. 8 a and b). Gas-phase AcOH as a monomer (1800 cm−1 and 1776 cm−1) or dimer (1730 cm−1) exhibited ν(CO) vibrational peaks on every catalyst. The single-bond carboxyl stretching ν(CO) and OH bending δ(OH) were also the characteristic vibrations of AcOH (1280–1290 cm−1) and (1180 cm−1) [90,91]. The sharp peak at 1440 cm−1 was attributed to the ν12 vibrations of C2H4 [20,90]. After deconvolution, the shoulder peak at 1704 cm−1 was assigned to KH(OAc)2 dimer ν(CO) [20]. This peak was only found on Pd-Au/SiO2 because Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs exhibited a vibration at 1670 cm−1, hiding the weaker 1704 cm−1 signal. The 1670 cm−1 vibration on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs was attributed to acetate adsorbed on surface Pd in a monodentate mode. A reported study [20] suggested that this vibration should be at 1680 cm−1. The shift of this vibrational mode suggested the presence of electron-rich Pd in the catalyst, with the extra electrons feeding back into ν(CO) [92,93]. Under reaction conditions, all catalysts showed characteristic signals of VAM at 1630 cm−1, 1380 cm−1, and 1220 cm−1, which were attributed to ν(CC), δ(CH3) and ν(CO), respectively (Fig. 8c and d) [20,90]. Fig. S19 also provided the characteristic signals for VAM directly adsorbed on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs. Unfortunately, the ν(CO) signal of VAM overlapped completely with the gas-phase AcOH monomer signal. A strong ν(CO) vibrational absorption on Pd-Au/TiO2-OVs was observed at 1670 cm−1, suggesting the accumulation of CH3COO* as an intermediate species, consistent with DFT calculations. The dehydrogenation reaction of AcOH was accelerated, while the consumption of CH3COO* (coupling of C2H4* and CH3COO*) was the rate-determining step. This directly led to the accumulation of CH3COO*, which was observable from in situ DRIFTS spectra. Detailed DFT and in situ DRIFTS together demonstrated that electron-rich Pd-Au NPs accelerated VAM production from ethylene by enhancing O2 activation, removing surface H* species, and AcOH dehydrogenation. 4 Conclusions For the synthesis of VAM from ethylene using Pd-Au bimetallic catalysts, we proposed a catalyst using TiO2 as the support, which offered a significant improvement over the conventional SiO2-supported catalysts. Metal-support interactions was established between TiO2 and Pd-Au NPs, leading to higher metal dispersion and the formation of smaller nanoparticles (1.9 nm) compared to those supported on SiO2 (3.9 nm). The hydrogen spillover facilitated by the Pd-Au NPs during reduction process promoted the formation of OVs. Excessively high reduction temperatures led to NPs sintering, which reduced the OVs content due to the decreased metal-support interface. The variation in OVs content was closely linked to the electronic state of the NPs, which also corresponded with the changes in the TOF of the active sites. The highest TOF of the catalyst and STY of vinyl acetate were achieved at a reduction temperature of 400 °C, despite some oxide coverage due to the SMSI that reduced the number of active sites. DFT and AIMD calculations confirmed that OVs played a critical role in promoting and stabilizing electron-rich Pd-Au NPs. Electron-rich Pd-Au NPs lowered the coupling energy barrier between C2H4* and CH3COO*, improved O2 adsorption and activation, and promoted AcOH dehydrogenation, as confirmed by in situ DRIFTS. This study offered a promising approach for enhancing the catalytic performance of Pd-Au catalysts in VAM synthesis from ethylene. The electronic effect induced by metal-support interactions could also be applicable to other oxidation reactions driven by noble metals. coredata.dc:description: The reaction of ethylene and acetic acid to produce vinyl acetate (VAM) was investigated on Pd-Au nanoparticles (NPs) supported on TiO2. Compared with the commercial catalyst Pd-Au/SiO2, Pd-Au/TiO2 exhibited a higher turnover frequency (TOF), likely due to the formation of smaller Pd-Au NPs (∼1.9 nm) and metal support interactions (MSI) between TiO2 with Pd-Au NPs. We found that the oxygen vacancies (OVs) of the TiO2 were regulated by adjusting the reduction temperature, facilitating electron transfer from TiO2 to the Pd-Au NPs, leading to enhanced MSI. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (In situ DRIFTs) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicated that the electron-rich Pd-Au NPs of Pd-Au/TiO2 catalyst enhanced O2 activation for increased TOF, and also promoted AcOH dehydrogenation and the key reaction of ethylene and acetate coupling. Our findings demonstrated that reducible supports could effectively influence the electronic properties of Pd-Au NPs through the construction of MSI, thereby enhancing catalytic activity.
